description: From Middle English provynce, from Anglo-Norman province, Middle French province, from Latin pr≈çvincia (‚Äúterritory brought under Roman domination; official duty, office, charge, province‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *pr≈çw- (‚Äúright judge, master‚Äù). Cognate with Gothic êçÜêçÇêå∞êåøêåæêå∞ (frauja, ‚Äúlord, master‚Äù), Old English frƒìa (‚Äúruler, lord, king, master‚Äù). Replaced Old English boldƒ°et√¶l. See also frow.

entries.meaning: A region of the earth or of a continent; a district or country. [from 14th c.]
An administrative subdivision of certain countries, including Canada and China. [from 14th c.]
examples: All of Fort McMurray, with the exception of Parson‚Äôs Creek, was under a mandatory evacuation order on Tuesday, said Robin Smith, press secretary for the regional municipality of Wood Buffalo in the Canadian province [of Alberta].

entries.meaning: (Roman history) An area outside Italy which is administered by a Roman governor. [from 14th c.]
examples: He reminded his audience of events in 88BC, when the same Mithridates invaded the Roman province of Asia, on the western coast of Turkey.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) An area under the jurisdiction of an archbishop, typically comprising a number of adjacent dioceses. [from 14th c.]
examples: In 1309, neither the Archbishop of Canterbury nor his suffragans would attend in Parliament while the Archbishop of York had the cross borne erect before him in the province of Canterbury.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) An area under the jurisdiction of a provincial within a monastic order.
(in the plural, chiefly with definite article) The parts of a country outside its capital city. [from 17th c.]
examples: To-day the first part of the new Indian Constitution comes into force with the granting of a large measure of autonomy to the provinces.

entries.meaning: An area of activity, responsibility or knowledge; the proper concern of a particular person or concept. [from 17th c.]
examples: Just as money is the province of the economy and truth the province of science and scholarship, so love is the province of the family (Niklas Luhmann).
